body:
I feel like it's more like a benefit but what we can do is have a minimal
package and have that "reccomend" installing golang-doc etc so if you
install with apt-get install --no-install-recommends you get minimal other
wise you get the whole thing

On Thursday, March 31, 2016, Andrew Gerrand <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> @jfrazelle <https://github.com/jfrazelle> no worries.
>
> I've been thinking about what the final form of these packages should be.
>
> IIUC, the Debian packaging guidelines are what gave us the multiple
> packages today: golang-go, golang-doc,golang-src`, etc.
>
> Do we want to be shipping multiple packages from our official apt
> repository? For simplicity's sake, it makes sense to me to provide a single
> golang package, which is more or less equivalent to untarring to
> /usr/local/go and updating PATH.
>
> The major downside of this is that some users will get more than they want
> or need. For instance, everyone on amd64 would get the
> race-detector-enabled runtime and standard library. But to me that doesn't
> seem a significant drawback.
>
> @mwhudson <https://github.com/mwhudson>, @jfrazelle
> <https://github.com/jfrazelle> what do you think about this?
